bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, November 21, 1941

div1.p: Hench wants to know what it would cost to buy the remains of the site of Camp Lazear. Hench discusses his plans to memorialize the site.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, November 21, 1941
div1.opener:
Rochester, Minnesota
November 21, 1941
Senor Adrian Macia
Manzana de Gomez 325
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senor Macia:
div1.p:
You must have wondered why I have been silent for so long. I realize
that I have long owed you a letter but the press of my professional work has kept
me from writing you. My last contact with you was in April when Mr. Moran and I
rather impolitely chased you about town in order to get the certificate of possession
of the little building at Finca San Jose before my plane left for the States.

Permit me to send you by separate post (regular mail) 5 copies of an article
on the Conquest of Yellow Fever which was just published in an American Medical
magazine. In it you will find a copy of the photograph of your good self with Mr.
Moran, Senor Zunzunegui and myself. I hope you do not mind my publishing your photo-
graph. Indeed I hope that it will please you to establish publicly your interesting
connection with this historic site. I have now in preparation another paper to be
entitled “The Identification of Camp Lazear” (or some such title) which I will pub-
lish with Senors Moran and Pogolotti as co-authors. Without their help I could never
have found the spot and without your real interest and generosity I could never have
hoped to memorialize the spot for the permanent edification of all who may be brought
to see it and for the permanent glorification of those great Cuban and American physi-
cians who conquered yellow fever. My special purpose in writing you now is to ask
you several very important questions.

list.item:
1. What would it cost me to buy the remains of the site of Camp Lazear?
I imagine I would want that part bounded by the fence behind the little houses near
where Senor Zunzunegui lives (this to be the “western” boundary, i.e. about on a
line with the northern extension of Calle Luis Carrero), the “southern” boundary to
be about Pablo Calzadilla (behind the site where Building No. 2 was), the “eastern”
boundary to be such as not to interfere with the present lime kilm, the “northern”
boundary to be sufficiently behind the remains of Building No. 1 so as to protect it
and yet not take in any of the old quarry. I may not have my boundaries and directions
quite accurate but I am sure you will know what I mean. If we go ahead with this we
should have enough land (but not too much) to make a decent-sized plot. When I talked
to you in April you were hopeful that your partners who share the deed to this property
might become more interested in this venture and might even be willing to become im-
portant and early contributors by offering their share in this little property. The
spot is so historical and can be made so interesting and attractive (if my hopes and
plans come true) that I believe in the long run they might be very proud to be listed
as among the founders or donors of the memorial. At any rate you believed that even
if you could not enlist their full support they would be willing to help us by charg-
ing little more than a nominal amount or certainly an amount within my modest means.
Again let me assure you that my only motive is in the interest of medical history and
the proper recognition of a great dead done by great man. I would appreciate it
if you would present a copy of my Hygeia article to each of your partners so that they
may get a better understanding of the significance of the spot.

2. Do you know whether Mr. Moran was able to get the remains of Building
No. 1 temporarily repaired? I have written him twice about this but have had no
answer, undoubtedly because of the press of work upon him. He has been such a loyal
friend and faithful colleague in this venture that I have no doubt he has done what he
could. But of course steps will have to be made to protect it permanently, not
Senor Adrian Macia
- 2 -
November 21, 1941
temporarily.

3. If I am able to purchase the camp site can you give me any idea of
how much the yearly taxes on it would be? I believe the size of the ground we want
will be only about 150 yards square; am I right in that estimate?

item.p:
4. I am hoping to see erected over the Building No. 1 (to be either
moved nearer Camp Columbia or left on the present site) a suitable permanent building
of one story in height, characteristic Cuban architecture and construction, size
about 100 x 50 feet (more or less, perhaps less) arranged roughly according to the
enclosed crude plan. It would probably need no cellar or excavated foundation and
a minimal of heating and plumbing. My ideas are not yet crystallized and I would
welcome suggestions on your part. There should be room for a caretaker certainly
by day, perhaps his simple living quarters by night. There should be a small public
rest room (i.e. lavatories for men and women) and in one corner of the building a
small section (counter, display cases and desk) where simple souvenirs might be
sold (photographs, post cards, a booklet on the history of the spot, etc.) by the
caretaker. The whole thing should be simple and inexpensive yet dignified and per-
manent. There should be a sky-light over the central part of the roof so as to admit
extra light unless this is too expensive, in which case adequate electric lighting
should be provided.

Can I ask you to give me a rough idea of how much such a little building
would cost (1) to erect (2) to maintain yearly? Could I perhaps interest you in
helping in the plans and building of such a little shrine? In asking you these
questions now I know you will realize that all of my plans are tentative and in the
formative stage, my resources are distinctly limited and I must ask you for this
help without as yet committing myself to anything definite or putting myself under
any obligation to pay for costly plans and specifications now.

list.item:
5. If the Cuban authorities, in accepting this memorial, strongly desire
the building to be moved to the “false site” of Campamento Lazear (across the railroad
track from Camp Columbia) can you give me any idea how much it would cost to move
the little building to the new site? Could it be moved in one piece on a large
truck (after being temporarily spliced together with boards, chains or what not)?
You recall the building is only 14 x 20 feet.

6. Have you any idea what it would cost to place on the sites of buildings
one and two a simple boulder or simple shaft with a bronze plaque (i.e. one on each
site) telling what had formerly been there, each plaque to be perhaps 2 or 3 feet
by 3 or 4 feet square?

div1.p:
In asking these questions I do so because of the fact that I know of
your sincere interest in the project and sympathy with me in it. You have amply
demonstrated this already by your kind and most generous transference of the
little building to me. Happily also you are an architect and engineer and, unless
I am greatly mistaken, you belong to that group of civic minded individuals who
delight in beautifying and preserving historical and civic sites and monuments.

As soon as I receive the above information from you, it is my plan to
set up a committee of civic and historically minded persons in this country and in
Havana to help me see this project through and to act as advisers and councillors.
Already several distinguished Americans have tentatively consented to join me in
Senor Adrian Macia
- 3 -
November 21, 1941
this venture; these include the daughter of Walter Reed, the widow of Dr. Lazear,
3 of the high ranking army medical officers in Washington who knew Reed well, several
very distinguished physicians, etc. I hope also that in Cuba we can have such men
as Drs. Finlay, Ramos, Albertini, Recio, Miss Agramonte, Senora Rojas, and others on
it, not to mention yourself and Mr. Moran of course. Perhaps too we can enlist the
interest and patronage of the President of the Cuban Republic as well as other govern-
mental personages in Washington and Havana so that in time the spot can be dedicated
appropriately. But before convening such an advisory committee I must have at least
some of the data I have herein requested of you. The first thing to be done, of
course, is to see how much the camp site will cost and then to find out if the Cuban
government has enough land near the Military Hospital on which to set up a memorial
or whether a second piece of land must be bought there. I am asking Mr. Moran and Mr.
Pogolotti to advise me as to the area near the Military Hospital owned by the govern-
ment.

Believe me, my dear Senor Macia, I do most sincerely appreciate your many
past favors and generosity. I know that you are a very busy man and I hesitate to
burden you with these questions. But we have a little saying here in the States
which I believe applies in this instance: “If you really want something done,
ask a busy man to do it:“

I will await your reply with eagerness and again let me express my gratitude
for your continued interest in what I believe to be a most worthy and altruistic
venture. I need not tell you that this is not to be a monument to Americans, but a
monument to glorify Finlay and Delgado equally with Reed and his associates. They
are inseparable in history. Indeed it is to be more than that--it is to be a
monument honoring the medical profession of Cuba and America and their humanitarian
ideals. It delights me that I can work in a small way toward a better understanding
between the Cuban and American people. Especially in times like these it is so
terribly important to strengthen the bonds of friendship and comradeship between the
peoples of our two republics.
div1.closer: Yours most sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
